questions.question: What effect does a contra-asset account have on a balance sheet?
questions.answer: A contra asset has a credit balance and therefore a negative effect on total assets
correctAnswer: A contra asset has a credit balance and therefore a negative effect on total assets
options: A contra asset is not an accounting term
A contra asset has a credit balance and therefore a negative effect on total assets
A contra asset with a positive balance will increase overall liabilities
A contra asset has a debit balance and therefore a positive effect on total assets

questions.answer: A person who has record-keeping responsibility should not make journal entries.
correctAnswer: A person who has record-keeping responsibility should not make journal entries.

options: Accruals are past cash receipts and payments, while deferrals are expected future cash receipts and payments.

questions.question: How are the three financial statements (income statement, balance sheet, and cash flow statement) linked?
questions.answer: The net income goes to the retained earnings and the cash flow statement
questions.explanation: [source]`'MT: odd qns. But it should be net profit "npat" flows to retained earnings, and also starts the cashflow statement (so all linked and not independent). Assets are in the balance sheet, and net income is in the income statement. npat goes to retained earnings, not gross profit.`
correctAnswer: The net income goes to the retained earnings and the cash flow statement
options: Only the assets are reflected in the cash flow statement, and the net income expenses correlate with the liabilities.
The net income goes to retained earnings, but the cash flow remains independent.
The gross profit goes to retained earnings, and the shareholder equity total is added to the cash flow statement
The net income goes to the retained earnings and the cash flow statement

questions.question: What does the degree of operating leverage represent?
questions.answer: how much the operating income of a company will change in response to a change in sales

correctAnswer: how much the operating income of a company will change in response to a change in sales
options: how much the value of capital assets will change in response to a change in sales
how much the operating income of a company will change in response to a change in sales
the valuation of assets to determine how much additional debt the company can borrow
how much the sales of a company will change in response to a change in operating income

questions.question: Which statement is false?
questions.answer: The balanced scorecard ensures the organization's profitability aligns with director compensation and dividend expectations.
questions.explanation:
[Reference](http://www.managerialaccounting.org/Balanced%20Scorecard.htm)
`'MT: BSC is on improving efficiency - deliver goals and how to measure that quantitatively or qualitatively. Nothing to do with how to compensate'`

options: The balanced scorecard aligns an organization's operational activities with its mission.
The balanced scorecard focuses on four primary areas: financial, customer, internal process, and learning and growth. (def true)
The balanced scorecard measures, tracks, and reports on a balance of qualitative and financial data and metrics. (def true)
The balanced scorecard ensures the organization's profitability aligns with director compensation and dividend expectations.

options: Current liabilities are obligations owed after 12 months.
Current liabilities should be included under long-term liabilities.

correctAnswer: Variable costs per unit remain constant and fixed costs per unit vary.
options: Variable costs per unit remain constant and fixed costs per unit vary.
Fixed costs per unit remain constant and variable costs per unit vary.
Both total variable costs and total fixed costs vary.
Both total variable costs and total fixed costs remain constant.

questions.question: What is the formal method of analysis applied by management to identify appropriate cost drivers and effects on the costs of production?
questions.explanation: [Reference]Activity analysis involves studying and evaluating the activities and processes within an organization to understand their cost implications. It helps in identifying the key activities that drive costs and analyzing their relationship with various cost drivers. By understanding these relationships, management can make informed decisions to optimize costs and improve overall efficiency.

questions.question: When independent auditors can maintain their actual independence, it is referred to as independence in \_\_\_\_.
questions.explanation:
[Reference](https://www.journalofaccountancy.com/issues/2001/apr/independenceandpublicperceptionwhyweneedtocare.html)
`In Accounting Series Release no. 269, the SEC defined independence in fact and independence in appearance as separate but equally necessary factors in establishing the auditor’s objectivity and integrity when certifying financial statements filed with the commission by an issuer of securities. Few would debate that independence in fact—that is, that the auditor is unbiased—is essential to the validity of an audit.`

questions.question: When applying a cost-volume-profit analysis (CVP), certain assumptions must be respected. Which answer is _not_ one of these assumptions?
questions.answer: Actual unit variable cost will vary over the production range.
questions.explanation:
[Reference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cost%E2%80%93volume%E2%80%93profit_analysis#Assumptions)
> CVP assumes the following:
>
> - Constant sales price;
> - Constant variable cost
> - Constant total fixed cost
> - Units sold equal units produced.
>
> These are simplifying, largely linearizing assumptions, which are often implicitly assumed in elementary discussions of costs and profits.
correctAnswer: Actual unit variable cost will vary over the production range.
options: The unit sales price will remain constant.
Actual unit variable cost will vary over the production range.
The cost behavior is expressed as intersecting straight lines.
The unit fixed cost will decrease.

correctAnswer: A new average is calculated under the average cost method after each sale.
options: FIFO cost of goods sold will be the same as in a periodic inventory system.
Average costs are based entirely on unit cost simple averages.
LIFO cost of goods sold will be the same as in a periodic inventory system.
A new average is calculated under the average cost method after each sale.

questions.question: What type of cost changes in proportion to a company's production volume?
What do you call the benefit sacrificed when one option is chosen over another?
The actual price of a widget is $10 and the budgeted price is $7. What is the price variance for 1,000 widgets?
questions.explanation:
> Actual Cost = $10 per widget
> Budgeted Cost = $7 per widget
> Quantity = 1,000 widgets
Price Variance = (Actual Cost - Budgeted Cost) x Quantity
Price Variance = ($10 - $7) x 1,000
Price Variance = $3 x 1,000
Price Variance = $3,000
Therefore, the price variance for 1,000 widgets is $3,000.
